Award.AwardTitle: Multiple-scale mathematical models of ultra-short-pulse modelocked lasers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop new mathematical models of mode-locked lasers. Models will take into account descriptions of the optical and electronic components, and the coupling between them, on multiple time scales. The different time scales will be exploited to provide analytical methods and computational tools by which the nonlinear dynamics of the laser can be analyzed. These mathematical techniques will allow a careful study of the fundamental factors governing the existence and stability of pulse solutions, including a determination as to how noise affects these lasers' precision.

Recent advances have ushered in a new era of extremely stable ultra-short modelocked lasers, with typical pulse durations of just a few femtoseconds. Such advanced devices are important as precise sources for ultraviolet and infrared spectroscopy (e.g., for trace gas sensing) and optical and microwave waveform generation (e.g., for low noise microwave sources). They are also an essential component in optical atomic clocks, next-generation timekeeping devices with accuracies several orders of magnitude better than current microwave atomic clocks. A goal of this project is to provide results capable of predicting the performance of femtosecond lasers and that will assist scientists and engineers who design and build them. Another important component of this project is the training of students. As part of this component, the PI will visit Delaware State University to assist in the mentoring of applied mathematics graduate students being advised in the field of nonlinear optics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is the mathematical modeling of mode­locked lasers stabilized by filtering and external phase modulation.  Such a device is, essentially, an optical ring cavity to which a gain medium and other components have been added.  If gain exceeds loss, circulating optical energy builds in the cavity until losses and gain balance. If the optical wavelength­-dependent dispersion in the cavity is chosen property, the circulating optical energy is not a continuous beam, but rather organizes into one or more pulses that circulate in the cavity.  Noise from the amplifier, however, produces jitter in the pulses' amplitudes, positions, etc.  We have used mathematical models of this process to investigate the interaction between the noise and the circulating optical pulses.
The amount of noise added per pass by the amplifier in the ring cavity is small relative to the energy in a pulse; thus, on each pass the perturbation to the circulating pulse is small. The probability of large changes in the pulses is therefore also small -- ­essentially, many perturbations must combine coherently in similar directions over many passes for a large deviation to build up.  Large deviations nevertheless do arise because the nonlinear Schroedinger (NLS) equation that governs the propagation of such pulses possesses solutions with arbitrary amplitude, phase, position and frequency, and perturbations that change these parameters are not resisted. To help stabilize pulses in such directions, additional components are added to the mode­locked laser, such as nonlinear gain and time­ dependent phase modulation. Such components stabilize specific amplitudes, positions, etc., in the ring cavity.  The effects of these added components are also often assumed to produce small perturbations, however, so as to not distort the underlying pulses excessively.  A further complication is that although the noise added to the system is Gaussian, the nonlinear dynamics transform the output noise so that probability distributions associated with pulse parameters can be decidedly non-­Gaussian.  The specific objectives of this work have been to investigate the details of how large deviations in such a system can grow, to determine the probabilities associated with these deviations, and to learn how these probabilities depend upon the system parameters.   The methods we have developed and continue to work on are designed with the various specific features of these systems in mind.  Note that the smaller the probability of a specific large deviation, the more stable the modelocked laser. The analysis evaluates, therefore, in terms of resistance to noise, the performance characteristics of such devices and the mechanisms by which errors can arise.   
First of all, we have developed an iterative method capable of determining large deviations and their associated probabilities. Essentially, the method works by assuming the most probable noise perturbations have been found that produce a given pulse deformation (e.g., produce a large amplitude change), and then asks what additional perturbations most probably produces a slightly larger change. Finding that perturbed state can be formulated as a constrained optimization problem, and thus to find large deviations in general one obtains a sequence of optimization problems.
We have also developed methods to deal with large deviations where the coupling between the different modes is significant. We have determined in this case that there are often multiple locally­ optimal paths, and to obtain good probability estimates one must include these multiple paths and how the paths switch (i.e., bifurcate) as one varies the system parameters.   This shows that the problem is more complicated than one might anticipate, and explains why previous attempts at understanding this problem failed. The method allows an enumeration of the locally ­optimal (i.e., most probable) solutions, however, and so allows the piece­wise optimal (in the limit of small noise) probability distribution to be determined. We are continuing to investigate the ramifications of this discovery and refining the methods.
We have also investigated the situation where a pulse grows from noise, i.e., initially a pulse is absent. In this case, the manner in which the optical pulse energy is detected becomes important for determining a large deviation at the measurement device ­­­ the detection mechanism itself determines which perturbations are most significant. We have found that reformulating this problem as a quadratic trust­ region subproblem allows finding the most probable noise perturbations that produce large pulse deformations at the output.
Personnel working on this project (i.e., a graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow) have received interdisciplinary training on both mathematical techniques and on the details of optical systems. The training has been designed to provide both breadth and depth --­­ it has both general components and specifics related to the proposed research.
